thread.title: Vegan group plans protest at Meatstock
thread.title_full: Vegan group plans protest at Meatstock

author: Zizi Sparks
title: Vegan group plans protest at Meatstock
text:
Vegan group plans protest at Meatstock ZIZI SPARKS Last updated 11:56, February 25 2017 SUPPLIED 
Members of the Starfish Bobby Calf Project protesting outside the Waikato Museum. 
Vegan animal rights group Starfish Bobby Calf Project will be protesting outside the Meatstock festival against the "mindless consumption" of meat. 
Founder Lynley Tulloch said the organisation decided to do a demonstration and protest at the festival, to try and raise awareness around "how animals suffer on the way to the barbecue". 
"Meat has become a real commodity that's being marketed and this festival represents this mindless consumption of animals and the way they get caught up in the capitalist machine of consumption," Tulloch said. SUPPLIED 
The Starfish Bobby Calf Project has held multiple peaceful protests during its three-year existence. 
Tulloch is hoping about 20 picketers will join her at Auckland's ASB Showgrounds and promised the protest will be peaceful. 
READ MORE: 
"The point we're trying to make is we want to make visible the animals' plight behind the scenes," Tulloch said. Meatstock NZ 
Meatstock NZ is currently underway at the ASB Showgrounds in Auckland and it ends on February 26. 
"People are consuming without thinking." 
The protesters will be at the festival between noon and 1pm handing out information to those that want it. 
"We can give information to people who want to know more... It's something they may come back and reflect on later." 
Starfish Bobby Calf Project was established three years ago to rescue a handful of bobby calves and raise awareness of the animals in the dairy industry. Since then, it has become an activist and animal rights platform, Tulloch said. Ad Feedback 
The co-director of Meatstock, Simon Luke, said the protesters won't be met with any negativity and he's happy for them to be present at the festival. 
"These people have the right to that opinion. There's always people on both sides of the fence with that particular topic [animal rights]," Luke said. 
"My personal opinion is about making sure people communicate with one another to make sure these protesters wouldn't feel like we'd be encouraging nasty or negative feedback. In return we would expect they wouldn't be nasty to our customers. I'm more than happy to have them voice their opinion." - Stuff
